revision.text:
[[File:Саблинский хребет.jpg|thumb|right|425px|Sablinsky Ridge, [[Yugyd Va National Park]], on the west slope of the Northern [[Ural Mountains]]]] There are currently 48 '''national parks''' in [[Russia]], a list of which is given below. Together they cover approximately {{convert|155672|km2| sqmi|sp=us}}. ==Overview== [[File:RussianNationalParksmap.jpg|thumb|right|430px|Map of national parks in Russia]] The oldest parks in Russia are [[Sochinsky National Park|Sochinsky]] and [[Losiny Ostrov National Park|Losiny Ostrov]] (1983); [[Samarskaya Luka National Park|Samarskaya Luka]] (1984); [[Marii Chodra National Park|Mariy Chodra]] (1985); [[Bashkiriya National Park|Bashkiriya]], [[Prielbrusye National Park|Prielbrusye]], [[Pribaykalsky National Park|Pribaykalsky]], and [[Zabaykalsky National Park|Zabaykalsky]] (1986).Russian Nature Press According to the law on the [[protected areas of Russia]], national parks are areas of land and water devoted to nature protection, ecological education, and scientific research. They contain sites of particular ecological, historical and aesthetic value. Regulated tourism is permitted.[http://oopt.info/oopt_statut.html "About Special Protected Nature Areas"], a Russian Federation federal law of March 14, 1995.{{ru icon}}Biodiversity Conservation Centre Moscow The area of each park is divided into zones according to various functions. There should be a strictly protected area managed as a [[zapovednik]], and also recreational and buffer zones in which economic activity is allowed, such as tourism, traditional land use, and benign forms of agriculture and forestry. The strictly protected function is sometimes fulfilled by a neighbouring official zapovednik; for instance, [http://oopt.info/barguz/index.html Barguzin Zapovednik] adjoins Zabaykalsky National Park on the east side of [[Lake Baikal]]. In 2001 [[Vodlozersky National Park]] received [[UNESCO]] [[Biosphere Reserve]] status, followed by [[Smolenskoye Poozerye National Park|Smolenskoye Poozerye]] and [[Ugra National Park]] in 2002, and two others ([[Valdaysky National Park|Valdaysky]] and [[Kenozersky National Park|Kenozersky]]) in 2004. The newest park is [[Bikin National Park]], created in late 2015. The national parks are currently the responsibility of the [[Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (Russia)]]. == List of national parks of Russia == {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="width:98%" !scope="col" |Name !scope="col" class="unsortable"|Photo !scope="col" |Location !scope="col" |Created !scope="col" |Park URL !scope="col" |Area !scope="col" class="unsortable"|Description |- !scope="row" | [[Alaniya National Park|Alaniya]] |[[File:Водопад Три Сестры на рассвете.jpg|150px|alt=Mountain peak and glacial valley, Alaniya NP]] |[[North Ossetia-Alania]]
{{coord|42|52|N|43|44|E|name=Alaniya|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1998}}
| [http://npalania.ru/ Ала́ния]
|{{convert|54926|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Alaniya lies on the north slope of the central [[Caucasus Mountains]]. The park includes the 13 km long [[Karaugom Glacier]], the deep forest valley of the [[Urukh River]], and steppe grasslands. Archaeological ruins dot the park, from the Bronze Age [[Koban culture]] to the medieval [[Alans]] people. The host Republic of [[North Ossetia-Alania]] takes its name from the Alans.{{cite web|title=Alaniya National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://npalnaia.ru/|publisher=FGBU Alaniya|accessdate=December 27, 2015}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} |- !scope="row" | [[Alkhanay National Park|Alkhanay]] |[[File:Национальный парк Алханай 2.jpg|150px|alt=Temple Gate rock formation, Alkhanay NP]] |[[Zabaykalsky Krai]]
{{coord|50|50|N|113|25|E|name=Alkhanay|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1999}}
| [http://alkhana.ru/ Алханай]
|{{convert|138234|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Sacred to the indigenous [[Buryats]] people, as well as modern Buddhists, Mt. Alkhanai is the central focus of the park. (The [[Dalai Lama]] has made two unofficial visits). The surroundings are a prime example of "[[Daurian forest steppe]]", in the transition zone between the Siberian [[taiga]] to the north, and the [[Mongolian steppe]] just to the south.{{cite web|title=Alkhanay National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://alkhana.ru/|publisher=FGBU Alkhanay|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Anyuysky National Park|Anyuysky]] |[[File:Анюй 3.JPG|150px|alt=Headwaters of Anyuy River, Anyuysky NP]] |[[Khabarovsk Krai]]
{{coord|49|26|N|136|33|E|name=Anyuysky|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1999}}
| [http://www.zapoved.ru/catalog/148/ Анюйский]
|{{convert|429370|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|The park is important because it creates an ecological corridor - from the low floodplain habitat of the [[Amur River]], up through the forested [[Anyuy River (Khabarovsk Krai)|Anyuy River]] basin, to the high levels of the [[Sikhote-Alin]] mountain range in the [[Russian Far East]]. The local indigenous people are the [[Nanai people]], traditionally a fishing and hunting culture.{{cite web|title=Anyuysky National Park (in Russian)|url=http://www.zapoved.ru/catalog/148/|publisher=Ministry of Natural Resources of the Russian Federation|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Bashkiriya National Park|Bashkiriya]] |[[File:Зимний пейзаж в районе Нугушского водохранилища.JPG|150px|alt=Bashkiriya in winter snow]] |[[Bashkortostan]]
{{coord|53|03|N|56|32|E|name=Bashkiriya|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1986}}
| [http://en.russia.edu.ru/russia/cities/ufa/1166/ Башкирия]
|{{convert|92000|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Bashkiriya covers a large contiguous forest and network of dissected river valleys on the southern end of the [[Ural mountains]]. The park is a buffer between the industrialized flat lands to the west, and the mountainous and sparsely-populated [[Shulgan-Tash Nature Reserve]] and Allyn-Solok ("Golden Bee Tree") entomological reserve to the east.{{cite web|title=Bashkiriya National Park (in Russian)|url=http://en.russia.edu.ru/russia/cities/ufa/1166/|publisher=Ministry of Education and Science of the Russian Federation|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Beringia National Park|Beringia]] |[[File:Road to Novoe Chaplino NPS.jpg|150px|alt=Beringia]] |[[Chukotka Autonomous Okrug]]
{{coord|64|22|N|173|18|E|name=Beringia|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|2013}}
| [http://www.beringiapark.ru/en/ Берингия]
|{{convert|3053233|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Until 11,000 BCE, the [[Beringia]] "land bridge" allowed humans to pass between Asia and North America. Russia's Beringia National Park is the western side of what is now the [[Bering Strait]], with the US [[Bering Land Bridge National Preserve]] in Alaska on the eastern side.{{cite web|title=Beringia National Park - Official Park Website (in English)|url=http://www.beringiapark.ru/en/|publisher=FGBU Beringia|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Bikin National Park|Bikin]] |[[File:Вид на долину р. Бикин с видовой площадки (гора Клин).jpg|150px|alt=Bikin]] |[[Primorsky Krai]]
{{coord|46|40|N|136|00|E|name=Bikin|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|2015}}
|[http://government.ru/en/docs/20381/ Бикин]
|{{convert|1160500|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Created Nov. 3, 2015, Bikin National Park protects the largest remaining old-growth mixed forest in the Northern Hemisphere, as well as the territory of 10% of all Amur tigers in the wild. The park also protects the forest culture of the 600 indigenous inhabitants that remain in the [[Bikin River]] basin, the [[Udeghes]] and [[Nanai people]].{{cite web|title=Directive Creating Bikin National Park|url=http://government.ru/en/docs/20381/|publisher=Ministry of Natural Resources of the Russian Federation|accessdate=January 10, 2016}} |- !scope="row" | [[Buzuluksky Bor National Park|Buzuluksky Bor]] |[[File:Buzuluksky Bor national park.jpg|150px|alt=Pine stand on river in Buzuluksky Bor NP]] |[[Samara Oblast]] / [[Orenburg Oblast]]
{{coord|53|00|N|52|7|E|name=Buzuluksky|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|2007}}
| [http://oopt.aari.ru/oopt/%D0%91%D1%83%D0%B7%D1%83%D0%BB%D1%83%D0%BA%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9-%D0%B1%D0%BE%D1%80 Бузулукский бор]
|{{convert|106000|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Buzuluksky Bor is the largest grove of isolated high pine trees in the world. Surrounded by a sea of steppes on the [[Eastern Russian Plain]] between the [[Volga River]] (west) and the southern [[Ural Mountains]] (to the east), the park is the sandy remains of what was once a river delta into the [[Caspian Sea]]. There is oil underneath Buzuluksky, adding pressure to the site.{{cite web|title=Buzuluksky Bor National Park (in Russian)|url=http://oopt.aari.ru/oopt/%D0%91%D1%83%D0%B7%D1%83%D0%BB%D1%83%D0%BA%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9-%D0%B1%D0%BE%D1%80|publisher=FGBU AARI PA (PA Russia)|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Chavash Varmane Bor National Park|Chavash Varmane Bor]] |[[File:Нацпарк "Чаваш вармане".jpg|150px|alt=Map with borders of Chavash Vermane Bor NP]] |[[Chuvashia]]
{{coord|54|45|N|47|08|E|name=Chavash Varmane Bor|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1993}}
| [http://www.npark21.ru/ Чаваш Вармане]
|{{convert|25200|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
| Chavash Varmane Bor is a large contiguous (unbroken) forest in the middle Volga River region. The park was created to serve the dual purpose of preserving biological diversity and the protection of a site representative of the [[Chuvash people]].{{cite web|title=Chavash Varmane Bor National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://www.npark21.ru/|publisher=FGBU Chavash Varmane Bor|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Chikoy National Park|Chikoy]] |[[File:Зеркальная гладь.jpg|150px|alt=Chikoy NP]] |[[Zabaykalsky Krai]]
{{coord|49|46|N|110|18|E|name=Chikoy|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|2014}}
| [http://www.zapoved.ru/catalog/258 Чикой]
|{{convert|666468|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
| The park is at the headwaters of the [[Chikoy River]], which flows west into the [[Selenga River]] and [[Lake Baikal]], 250 miles to the northwest. It is in the transition zone between the Siberian taiga to the north and Mongolian steppe to the south.{{cite web|title=Chikoy National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://www.zapoved.ru/catalog/258|publisher=Ministry of Natural Resources of the Russian Federation|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Kalevalsky National Park|Kalevalsky]] |[[File:Venehjarvi.jpg|150px|alt=Kalevalsky NP]] |[[Republic of Karelia]]
{{coord|64|59|N|30|13|E|name=Kalevalsky|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|2007}}
| [http://www.zapoved.ru/catalog/110/%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9-%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9-%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BA Калевальский]
|{{convert|74400|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|The Kalevalsky pine forest covers one of the last, large old-growth boreal pine forest in Europe. It is situated on the border between Russia and Finland at about the midpoint from south to north. The park is located in the Republic of Karelia. The Kalevala, an epic poem of Finnish and Karelian oral folklore, was drawn from this region.{{cite web|title=Kalevalsky National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://www.zapoved.ru/catalog/110/%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9-%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9-%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BA|publisher=Ministry of Natural Resources of the Russian Federation|accessdate=December 31, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Curonian Spit National Park (Russia)|Curonian Spit]] |[[File:Вид с озера Лебедь на залив.jpg|150px|alt=Kurshskaya Kosa NP]] |[[Kaliningrad Oblast]]
{{coord|55|08|N|20|48|E|name=Kurshskaya Kosa|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1987}}
| [http://www.park-kosa.ru/ Куршская коса]
|{{convert|6621|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|The [[Curonian Spit]] is a 98 km long, thin, curved sand-dune spit that separates the [[Curonian Lagoon]] from the [[Baltic Sea]] coast. Its southern portion lies within [[Kaliningrad Oblast]], Russia and its northern within southwestern [[Lithuania]]. It is a [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]] shared by the two countries.{{cite web|title=Kurshskaya Kosa National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://www.park-kosa.ru|publisher=FGBU Kurshskaya|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Kenozersky National Park|Kenozersky]] |[[File:Вечер на Лёкшмозере.jpg|150px|alt=Sts Peter and Paul Church in the village ofMorshchikhinskaya]] |[[Arkhangelsk Oblast]]
{{coord|62|05|N|38|12|E|name=Kenozersky|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1991}}
| [http://www.kenozero.ru/en Кенозерский ]
|{{convert|139663|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|The park has many cultural monuments, one being Porzhensky Pogost, which is St. George church with the bell-tower (both from the 18th century) surrounded by the wooden wall with gates and towers (1789). The park is on the divide between the Atlantic and Arctic basins. Since 2004, the National Park has the status of the UNESCO Biosphere Reserve.{{cite web|title=Kenozersky National Park - Official Park Website (in English)|url=http://www.kenozero.ru/en|publisher=FGBU Kenozersky |accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Khvalynsky National Park|Khvalynsky]] |[[File:Национальный парк «Хвалынский».jpg|150px|alt=Pine tree over wooded valley, Khvalynsky NP]] |[[Saratov Oblast]]
{{coord|53|00|N|52|7|E|name=Khvalynky|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1994}}
| [http://nasledie.sgu.ru/hvalinskiy_park Хвалынский]
|{{convert|25524|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Khvalynksy NP encompasses a raised plateau of chalk hills of the Volga Uplands, covered in mixed oak-linden and conifer forests, along the west side of the Volga River. It is about 1,000 km north of the Caspian Sea, in Saratov Oblast overlooking the Saratov Reservoir.{{cite web|title=Khvalynsky National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://nasledie.sgu.ru/hvalinskiy_park|publisher=Scientific Tourism, Saratov Oblast|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Losiny Ostrov National Park|Losiny Ostrov]] |[[File:Losiny Ostrov 2009-09-22.jpg|150px|alt=Upper Yauza swamp]] |[[Moscow Oblast]]
{{coord|53|52|N|37|47|E|name=Losiny Ostrov|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1983}}
| [http://elkisland.ru/ Лосиный Остров]
|{{convert|11600|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Literally, 'Moose Island', Losiny Ostrov is the first national park of Russia. It is located in Moscow and Moscow Oblast and is the third largest forest in a city of comparable size, after Table Mountain National Park (Cape Town) and Pedra Branca State Park (Rio de Janeiro).{{cite web|title=Losiny Ostrov National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://elkisland.ru/|publisher=FGBU Losiny Ostrov|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Mariy Chodra National Park|Mariy Chodra]] |[[File:TotEr.jpg|150px|alt=Tot-Er Lake, in NP Mariy Chodra]] |[[Mari El Republic]]
{{coord|56|09|N|48|22|E|name=Mariy Chodra|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1985}}
| [http://www.rusnature.info/zap/038.htm Марий Чодра]
|{{convert|36600|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Mariy Chodra was created to protect rare plants: more than 115 rare plant species are documented. There are fourteen tourist routes in the park; the most popular attractions being Yalchik, Glukhoye, and Kichiyer Lakes, the rafting on the Ilet and Yushut Rivers, Pugachov's Oak, and the Maple Mountain.{{cite web|title=Mariy Chodra National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://www.rusnature.info/zap/038.htm|publisher=FGBU Mariy Chodra|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Meshchyora National Park|Meshchyora]] |[[File:Meshchera04.jpg|150px|alt=Wetlands in Meshcheyora NP]] |[[Vladimir Oblast]]
{{coord|55|34|N|40|15|E|name=Meshcheyora|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1992}}
| [http://www.park-meshera.ru/ Мещёра]
|{{convert|118900|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Meshchyora NP covers extensive wetlands (swamps, peat bogs, rivers and lakes) - an extremely rich habitat for biodiversity - and pine/birch woodlands in the Meshchera Lowlands on the East European Plain in Vladimir Oblast, about 120 km east of Moscow. The area is associated with the medieval Meshchera tribe.{{cite web|title=Meshchyora National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://www.park-meshera.ru/|publisher=FGBU Meshchyora|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Meshchyorsky National Park|Meschyorsky]] |[[File:Национальный парк Мещерский.JPG|150px|alt=Meshcheyorsky NP]] |[[Ryazan Oblast]]
{{coord|55|08|N|40|10|E|name=Meschyorsky|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1992}}
| [http://xn----7sbqapgcdp0amfn3i.xn--p1ai/ Мещерский]
|{{convert|105014|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|"Meshchersky" (Мещёрский) National Park is not to be confused with "Meshchyora" (Мещёра) National Park, which is just to the north, over the border in Vladimir Oblast. The neighboring parks cover similar wetlands (swamps, peat bogs, rivers and lakes) and pine/birch woodlands in the Meshchera Lowlands.{{cite web|title=Meshchyorsky National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://xn----7sbqapgcdp0amfn3i.xn--p1ai/|publisher=FGBU Meshchyorsky|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Nechkinsky National Park|Nechkinsky]] |[[File:Нечкинский, Воткинский район.jpg|150px|alt=Coastline viewed from hill, Nechkinsky NP]] |[[Udmurt Republic]]
{{coord|56|41|N|53|47|E|name=Nechkinsky|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1997}}
| [http://www.nechkinsky.ru/ Нечкинский]
|{{convert|20753|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Nechkinsky NP is an important biological and cultural reserve of Udmurtia (the Udmurt Republic), situated in the middle valley of the Kama River, its tributary the Siva River, and the coastal part of the Votkinsk reservoir. The territory is mostly forest and river floodplains, with a number of ancient archaeological sites on the grounds. It is near the city of Izhevsk, on the west side of the [[Ural Mountains]].{{cite web|title=Nechkinsky National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://www.nechkinsky.ru/|publisher=FGBU Nechkinsky|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Nizhnyaya Kama National Park|Nizhnyaya Kama]] |[[File:Танаевские луга. Камско-Криушская пойма. Национальный парк "Нижняя Кама".jpg|150px|alt=Sign at border of Nizhnyaya Kama NP]] |[[Tatarstan]]
{{coord|55|48|N|52|19|E|name=Nizhnyaya Kama|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1991}}
| [http://nkama-park.ru/ Нижняя Кама]
|{{convert|26587|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
| Literally translated as "Lower Kama National Park", Nizhnyaya Kama is a national park in the center of Russia, located in Tukayevsky and Yelabuzhsky Districts of [[Tatarstan]]. It was established April 20, 1991 to protect coniferous (mostly pine) forests at the banks of the Kama River.{{cite web|title= National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://nkama-park.ru/|publisher=FGBU Nizhnyaya|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Onezhskoye Pomorye National Park|Onezhskoye Pomorye]] |[[File:Гроза над Паранинским ручьём.JPG|150px|alt=Onezhskoye Pomorye NP]] |[[Arkhangelsk Oblast]]
{{coord|64|47|N|37|18|E|name=Onezhskoye Pomorye|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|2013}}
| [http://onpomor.ru/about/nash-park.php Онежское Поморье]
|{{convert|201670|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|The park occupies much of the Onega Peninsula and adjacent parts of the White Sea. There are no all-season means of land transportation to the mainland. Most of the area is covered by forest.Moose, Eurasian brown bear, gray wolf, and red fox are common in the park. Beluga whale occurs in the White sea. In the winter, the sea is frozen.{{cite web|title=Onezhskoye Pomorye National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://onpomor.ru/about/nash-park.php|publisher=Ministry of Natural Resources and Ecology of the Russian Federation|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Orlovskoye Polesye]] |[[File:Зубр Европейский в дубовом лесу Орловского полесья.jpg|150px|alt=Orlovskoye_Polesye NP]] |[[Oryol Oblast]]
{{coord|53|28|N|35|3|E|name=Orlovskoye_Polesye|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1994}}
| [http://orlpolesie.ru/ Орловское полесье]
|{{convert|77745|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Orlovskoye Polesye is situated in the middle of the Central Russian Upland straddling the Znamensky and Khotynetsky districts of Oryol Oblast. The territory is a hills cut with ravines and gullies. The highest elevation is 250 meters above the sea level. In the low-lying areas there are muskeg with cranberries.{{cite web|title=Orlovskoye Polesye National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://onpomor.ru/|publisher=FGBU Orlovskoye Polesye|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Paanajärvi National Park|Paanajärvi]] |[[File:Vid na ozero Paanayarvi.JPG|150px|alt=Paanajärvi NP]] |[[Republic of Karelia]]
{{coord|66|29|N|37|18|E|name=Paanajärvi|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1992}}
| [http://parks.karelia.ru/paanajarvi/ Паанаярви]
|{{convert|104371|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Paanajärvi National Park is located in the Karelia Region of northern Europe, along the Finnish–Russian border. It protects 1,043.71 square kilometres (402.98 sq mi) of pristine Scandinavian and Russian Taiga ecoregion forest habitats, lakes, and rivers.{{cite web|title=Paanajärvi National Park - (in English)|url=http://parks.karelia.ru/paanajarvi/|publisher=European Commission 2007|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Pleshcheyevo Ozero National Park|Pleshcheyevo Ozero]] |[[File:Ple-oz-view01.jpg|150px|alt=Pleshcheyevo Ozero NP]] |[[Yaroslavl Oblast]]
{{coord|56|46|N|38|44|E|name=Pleshcheyevo Ozero|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1997}}
| [http://www.plesheevo-lake.ru/ Плещеево озеро]
|{{convert|23790|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Pleshcheyevo NP covers Lake Pleshcheyevo and surrounding areas. The lake is highly popular for recreational use, as an ecological habitat, and is a former resort for the Russian tsars. The lake is located about 130 km northeast of Moscow, in the basin of the Upper Volga. On the southeast shore is the resort town of Pereslavl-Zalessky, Yaroslavl Oblast.{{cite web|title=Pleshcheyevo Ozero National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://www.plesheevo-lake.ru/|publisher=FGBU Pleshcheyevo Ozero|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Pribaikalsky National Park|Pribaikalsky]] |[[File:Olkhonsky District Shamanka Rock.jpg|150px|alt=Shaman Rocks, Pribaikalsky NP]] |[[Irkutsk Oblast]]
{{coord|51|51|N|104|53|E|name=Pribaikalsky|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1986}}
| [http://baikal-1.ru/ Прибайкальский]
|{{convert|417300|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Pribaikalsky National Park covers the southwest coast of Lake Baikalin southeastern Siberia. The coastal strip includes some mountain ridges to the west as well as offshore islands such as Olkhon Island to the east. It is about 50 km southeast of the city of Irkutsk, Irkutsk Oblast.{{cite web|title=Pribaikalsky National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://baikal-1.ru/|publisher=FGBU Pribaikalsky|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Pripyshminskiye Bory National Park|Pripyshminskiye Bory]] |[[File:Pripshminskiye National Park borders.svg|150px|alt=Pripyshminskiye Bory NP]] |[[Sverdlovsk Oblast]]
{{coord|56|59|N|63|47|E|name=Pripyshminskiye Bory|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1993}}
|[http://www.nppbor.ru/ Припышминские Боры]
|{{convert|49050|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Pripyshminskie Bora is located on the western edge of the West Siberian Plain . It protects a complex of pine and birch forests. About 10% of the area is non-forested marshes, ponds, hayfields and pastures.{{cite web|title=Pripyshminskiye Bory National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://www.nppbor.ru/|publisher=FGBU Pripyshminskiye Bory|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Prielbrusye National Park|Prielbrusye]] |[[File:Mt. Elbrus in Russia.jpg|150px|alt=Prielbrusye NP]] |[[Kabardino-Balkaria]]
{{coord|43|21|N|42|34|E|name=Prielbrusye|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1986}}
| [http://elbrus-park.narod.ru/ Приэльбрусье]
|{{convert|1010200|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Prielbrusye is centered on Mt. Elbrus, the highest mountain in Europe at 5,632 meters above sea level. The relative isolation of steep gorges has led to high levels of endemism and biodiversity. The park is in the central Caucusus, just northwest of Alaniya National Park.{{cite web|title=Prielbrusye National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://elbrus-park.narod.ru/|publisher=FGBU Prielbrusye|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Russian Arctic National Park|Russian Arctic]] |[[File:Русло реки 4.JPG|150px|alt=Russian Arctic NP]] |[[Arkhangelsk Oblast]]
{{coord|75|42|N|60|54|E|name=Russian Arctic|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1986}}
| [https://web.archive.org/web/20090628110444/http://www.adm-nao.ru/?show=news&id=2460&PHPSESSID=9aa7498197d970c343758afd1e269f8d Русская Арктика]
|{{convert|1426000|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Russian Arctic National Park covers a large and remote area of the Arctic Ocean, the northern part of Novaya Zemlya (Severny Island), and Franz Josef Land.{{cite web|title=Russian Arctic National Park (in Russian)|url=http://adm-nao.ru/|publisher=Nenets Autoonomous Okrug|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Russky Sever National Park|Russky Sever]] |[[File:Maura hill.jpg|150px|alt=Russky Sever NP]] |[[Vologda Oblast]]
{{coord|59|57|N|38|34|E|name=Russky Sever|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1992}}
| [http://kirillovpark.narod.ru/ Русский Север]
|{{convert|166400|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|The name of the park means Russian North in Russian. The park protects natural and cultural landscapes around Kirillo-Belozersky Monastery and Ferapontov Monastery, places of great historical significance.{{cite web|title=Russky Sever National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://kirillovpark.narod.ru/|publisher=FGBU Russky Sever|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Samarskaya Luka National Park|Samarskaya Luka]] |[[File:Вид на Усинский курган.jpg|150px|alt=Samarskaya Luka NP]] |[[Samara Oblast]]
{{coord|53|18|N|49|50|E|name=Samarskaya Luka|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1984}}
| [http://www.npsamluka.ru/ Самарская Лука]
|{{convert|134000|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|The park (in English, "Samara Bend") is on the 180-degree bend of the Volga River as it flows south by the City of Samara. It is on the shore of the Kuibyshevskoye water reservoir, and on the north it has a border with Zhigulevsky Zapovednik. Most of the bedrock is [[karst]] (limestone) formation. {{cite web|title=Samarskaya Luka National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://www.npsamluka.ru/|publisher=FGBU Samarskaya Luka|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Saylyugemsky National Park|Saylyugemsky]] |[[File:Valley of the Yungur River.jpg|150px|alt=Saylyugemsky NP]] |[[Altai Republic]]
{{coord|49|31|N|88|37|E|name=Saylyugemsky|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|2010}}
|[http://www.zapoved.net/index.php/News/%D0%A0%D0%B5%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%8B/%D0%A1%D0%B8%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BE%D0%BA%D1%80%D1%83%D0%B3/%D0%A0%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BF%D1%83%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%90%D0%BB%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%B9/%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B9%D0%BB%D1%8E%D0%B3%D0%B5%D0%BC%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9 Сайлюгемский]
|{{convert|118380|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Created as a special preserve for the Altai Snow Leopard and the Altai mountain sheep (argali), Saylyugemsky National Park rises in the Altai-Sayan Mountains, on the border between Russia and Mongolia.{{cite web|title=Saylyugemsky National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://www.zapoved.net/index.php/News/%D0%A0%D0%B5%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%8B/%D0%A1%D0%B8%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%BE%D0%BA%D1%80%D1%83%D0%B3/%D0%A0%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BF%D1%83%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%90%D0%BB%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%B9/%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B9%D0%BB%D1%8E%D0%B3%D0%B5%D0%BC%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9|publisher=Ministry of Natural Resources of the Russian Federation|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Sebezhsky National Park|Sebezhsky]] |[[File:Sebezh.JPG|150px|alt=Sebezhsky NP]] |[[Pskov Oblast]]
{{coord|56|16|N|28|30|E|name=Sebezhsky|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1996}}
| [http://seb-park.ru/ Себежский]
|{{convert|50021|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Sebezhsky National Park is located in the southwestern part of Sebezhsky District, where the national park is located, is essentially hilly landscape of glacial origin with many lakes. The area is forested, with pine, spruce, mixed, and alder forests.{{cite web|title=Sebezhsky National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://seb-park.ru/|publisher=FGBU Sebezhsky|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Shantar Islands National Park|Shantar Islands]] |[[File:Bowhead whales swimming in Lingolm strait by Vladislav Raevskii.JPG|150px|alt=Shantar Islands NP]] |[[Khabarovsk Krai]]
{{coord|55|00|N|137|30|E|name=Shantar Islands|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|2014}}
| [http://www.zapoved.ru/catalog/260/%D0%A8%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B5-%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0-%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9-%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BA Шантарские острова]
|{{convert|250000|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|The Shantar Islands are a group of 15 islands that lie off the coast of Khabarovsk Krai, in the Sea of Okhotsk. Most of the islands have rugged cliffs, and the highest point is 720 meters. They are home to Steller Sea Lions, seals, and Bowhead whales.{{cite web|title=[Shantar Islands National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://www.zapoved.ru/catalog/260/%D0%A8%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B5-%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0-%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9-%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BA|publisher=Ministry of Natural Resources of the Russian Federation|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Shorsky National Park|Shorsky]] |[[File:Смотровая площадка Шорский Национальны парк.jpg|150px|alt=Shorsky NP]] |[[Kemerovo Oblast]]
{{coord|52|35|N|88|20|E|name=Shorsky|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1989}}
| [http://www.shor-np.kemv.ru/ Шорский]
|{{convert|418000|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Shorsky National Park is a forested, mountainous area in southwestern Siberia, where The West Siberian Plain meets the South Siberian Mountains. It is representative of areas with dark taiga tree cover (92% of the park is forested).{{cite web|title=Shorsky National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://www.shor-np.kemv.ru/|publisher=FGBU Shorsky|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Smolenskoye Poozerye National Park|Smolenskoye Poozerye]] |[[File:Sapsho lake.jpg|150px|alt=Smolenskoye Poozerye NP]] |[[Smolensk Oblast]]
{{coord|55|32|N|31|24|E|name=Smolenskoye Poozerye|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1992}}
| [http://www.poozerie.ru/en/home/ Смоленское Поозерье]
|{{convert|146237|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|"Smolensk Lakes" is a forest-wetland ecosystem of 35 lakes and surroundings in the northwest of Smolensk Oblast near the Russian border with Belarus. It is in the basin of the Daugava (river) (also called the "Western Dvina" River), about 40 miles (64 km) north of the city of Smolensk.{{cite web|title=Smolenskoye Poozerye National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://www.poozerie.ru/en/home/|publisher=FGBU Smolenskoye Poozerye|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Smolny National Park|Smolny]] |[[File:Alatyr river.jpg|150px|alt=Smolny NP]] |[[Republic of Mordovia]]
{{coord|54|50|N|45|40|E|name=Smolny|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1995}}
| [http://www.protectedplanet.net/smolny-national-park Смольный]
|{{convert|36500|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|The park has a representative lowland river environment, with a slow current. The lakes and swamps are mainly concentrated in the floodplain of the [[Alatyr River]]. Marshes are mainly lowland. A few bogs are located in the southern and central parts of the park. There are many springs. {{cite web|title=Smolny National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://www.protectedplanet.net/smolny-national-park|publisher=ProtectedPlanet.org|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Sochi National Park|Sochi]] |[[File:View to Krasnaya Polyana from Akhun mountain.JPG|150px|alt=Sochi NP]] |[[Krasnodar Krai]]
{{coord|43|05|N|39|43|E|name=Sochi|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1995}}
| [http://sochinp.ru/ Сочинский]
|{{convert|193737|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|The park occupies the Greater Sochi area, from the border with the Tuapsinsky District, between the mouths of Shepsi River and Magri River in the north-west, to the border with Abkhazia along the Psou River in the south-east, and between the Black Sea to the water divide crest of the Greater Caucasus.{{cite web|title=Sochi National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://sochinp.ru//|publisher=Sochi National Park|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Taganay National Park|Taganay]] |[[File:Останцы.jpg|150px|alt=Taganay NP]] |[[Chelyabinsk Oblast]]
{{coord|55|15|N|59|47|E|name=Taganay|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1991}}
| [http://taganay.ru/ Таганай]
|{{convert|56800|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Taganay is a group of mountain ridges in the Southern Urals, on the territory of Chelyabinsk Oblast, with the highest point rising 1178 m. above sea level.{{cite web|title=Taganay National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://taganay.ru/|publisher=FGBU Taganay|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Tarkhankut National Park|Tarkhankut]] |[[File:Атлеш, Чорноморський р-н, с. Оленівка 11.JPG|150px|alt=Tarhankut NP]] |[[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]]
{{coord|45|25|N|32|32|E|name=Tarhankut|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1991}}
| [http://parktarhankut.ru/ Тарханкутский]
|{{convert|10900|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|The park is located on the western tip of the Tarkhankut peninsula in the Black Sea region. The park is predominantly steppe areas Tarkhankut hills and beams (White, Castel, Ternovaya), which cut into the hill. The park surrounds virtually all West Coast.{{cite web|title=Tarkhankut National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://parktarhankut.ru/|publisher=FGBU Tarhankut|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Tunkinsky National Park|Tunkinsky]] |[[File:Irkut1.jpg|150px|alt=Tunkinsky NP]] |[[Buryatia]]
{{coord|51|41|N|102|08|E|name=Tunkinsky|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1991}}
| [https://web.archive.org/web/20120413232527/http://www.tunkapark.ru/en Тункинский]
|{{convert|1183662|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Tunkinsky is in south central Siberia, and covers a mountainous region centered on the Irkut River valley (also referred to as the Tunka Valley) that continues from the rift valley of Lake Baikalsouthwest to the border of Mongolia. To the north and west of the valley is the eastern edge of the [[Sayan Mountains]].{{cite web|title=Tunkinsky National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://www.tunkapark.ru/en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120413232527/http://www.tunkapark.ru/en|dead-url=yes|archive-date=April 13, 2012|publisher=FGBU Tunkinsky|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Udegeyskaya Legenda National Park|Udegeyskaya Legenda]] |[[File:Udegeyskaya Legende boundaries.svg|150px|alt=Udegeyskaya Legenda NP]] |[[Primorsky Krai]]
{{coord|45|49|N|135|25|E|name=Udegeyskaya Legenda|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1991}}
| [http://ud-legend.ru/ Удэгейская легенда]
|{{convert|103744|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Udege Legend covers the richest coniferous-deciduous forest on the western slope of the Central Sikhote-Alin mountains of the Russian Far East. The park is designed to protect west-slope river valley habitat, and to support the remnant of the indigenous Udege people. The area is known for abundant fishing and boating on the streams and rivers. It is also a refuge for the endangered Amur Tiger.{{cite web|title=Udegeyskaya Legenda National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://ud-legend.ru/|publisher=FGBU Udegeyskaya Legenda|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Ugra National Park|Ugra]] |[[File:The Ugra river.jpg|150px|alt=Ugra NP]] |[[Kaluga Oblast]]
{{coord|54|09|N|35|52|E|name=Ugra|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1997}}
| [http://parkugra.ru/ Угра]
|{{convert|98600|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Ugra National Park is a forested areas southwest of Moscow. It is located in the Kaluga region, the valleys of the rivers Ugra, Zhizdra, Vyssa and Oka.{{cite web|title=Ugra National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://parkugra.ru|publisher=FGBU Ugra|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Valdaysky National Park|Valdaysky]] |[[File:Valday lake NO.jpg|150px|alt=Valdaysky NP]] |[[Novgorod Oblast]]
{{coord|57|59|N|31|15|E|name=Valdaysy|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1990}}
| [http://valdaypark.ru/ Валдайский ]
|{{convert|158500|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Since 2004, the National Park has the status of a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve. Valdaysky National Park, which includes the town of Valday, Lake Valdayskoye, and the northern part of Lake Seliger, is one of the most popular tourist destinations in Central Russia and has well-developed tourist infrastructure.{{cite web|title=Valdaysky National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://valdaypark.ru/|publisher=FGBU Valdaysky|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Vodlozersky National Park|Vodlozersky]] |[[File:Vodlozersky National Park, Pilmas Ozero.jpg|150px|alt=Vodlozersky NP]] |[[Arkhangelsk Oblast]]
{{coord|62|39|N|37|05|E|name=Vodlozersky|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1991}}
| [http://oopt.info/index.php?oopt=657 Водлозерский]
|{{convert|428000|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|The park area includes Lake Vodlozero, the river basin of the Ileksa, the main inflow of the lake, and the upper course of the Vodla. In 2001, Vodlozersky was designate a UNESCO Biodiversity Reserve site.{{cite web|title=Vodlozersky National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://oopt.info/index.php?oopt=657|publisher=Ministry of Natural Resources of the Russian Federation|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Yugyd Va National Park|Yugyd Va]] |[[File:Саблинский хребет.jpg|150px|alt=Yugyd Va NP]] |[[Komi Republic]]
{{coord|62|25|N|58|47|E|name=Yugyd Va|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1994}}
| [http://www.yugydva.komi.com/ Югыд ва]
|{{convert|1891700|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|The Yugyd Va park covers a territory in the Northern Ural Mountains and adjacent foothills and flatlands. The entire park is within the Pechora River basin, i.e. west of the Europe-Asia continental divide; this means that all of it is geographically in Europe.{{cite web|title=Yugyd Va National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://www.yugydva.komi.com/|publisher=FGBU Yugyd Va|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Zabaykalsky National Park|Zabaykalsky]] |[[File:Baikal.Zmeinaya buhta.JPG|150px|alt=Zabaykalsky NP]] |[[Buryat Republic]]
{{coord|53|43|N|109|13|E|name=Zabaykalsy|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1986}}
| [http://www.zapoved.ru/catalog/122/ Забайкальский]
|{{convert|269000|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Zaybaykalsky National Park covers a section of the eastern shore of Lake Baikal.{{cite web|title=Zabaykalsky National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://www.zapoved.ru/catalog/122/|publisher=Ministry of Natural Resources of the Russian Federation|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Land of the Leopard National Park|Land of the Leopard]] |[[File:Amur Leopard (P.p. amurensis).jpg|150px|alt=Land of the Leopard NP]] |[[Primorsky Krai]]
{{coord|43|00|N|131|25|E|name=Land of the Leopard|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|2012}}
| [http://leopard-land.ru/ Земля леопарда]
|{{convert|80000|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
| The main aim of the park is to preserve and restore the population of the unique spotted cat - the Amur leopard, which number in Russia is now only about 50 individuals. Today, more than half of them lives in the "Land of the Leopard." In addition, there lives and another cat, listed in the Red Book - the Amur tiger.{{cite web|title=Land of the Leopard National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://leopard-land.ru/|publisher=FGBU Land of the Leopard|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Zov Tigra National Park|Zov Tigra]] |[[File:Геоботаническое описание.JPG|150px|alt=Zov Tigra NP]] |[[Primorsky Krai]]
{{coord|43|35|N|134|16|E|name=Zov Tigra|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|2007}}
| [http://zov-tigra.lazovzap.ru/ Зов Тигра]
|{{convert|83384|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Zov Tigra is a mountainous refuge for the endangered Amur Tiger. The park encompasses an area of 83,384 hectares (206,046 acres; 834 km2; 322 sq mi) on the far southeast coast of Russia's Far East in the federal district Primorsky Krai (in English, "Maritime Region").{{cite web|title=Zov Tigra National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://zov-tigra.lazovzap.ru/|publisher=FGBU Lazovsky/Zov Tigra|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} |- !scope="row" | [[Zyuratkul National Park|Zyuratkul]] |[[File:Zyuratkul range and Zyuratkul lake.JPG|150px|alt=Zyuratkul NP]] |[[Chelyabinsk Oblast]]
{{coord|54|51|N|58|56|E|name=Zyuratkul|type:landmark}}
|{{dts|1993}}
| [http://zuratkul.ru/ Зюраткуль]
|{{convert|88200|ha|mi2|1|sortable=on}}
|Notable features include Zyuratkul' Lake, a rare mountainous body of water for the Urals 754 m above sea level, with a surface area of 13,2 km2 and a maximum depth of 8 m. Water is slightly mineralised (≈50 mg/L). Because of its clear water and spectacular landscape around, Zyuratkul' is often called "Ural Ritsa".{{cite web|title=Zyuratkul National Park - Official Park Website (in Russian)|url=http://zuratkul.ru/|publisher=FGBU Zyuratkul|accessdate=December 27, 2015}} - |} ==See also== {{portal|Russia}} * [[Protected areas of Russia]] * [[Zapovednik|Nature Reserves (Zapovedniks) of Russia]] ==Footnotes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://oopt.info/np.html Biodiversity Conservation Center/Tsentr dikoy prirody, Moscow: page and map on each park, in Russian.] *[http://www.wild-russia.org/ Centre for Russian Nature Conservation/Russian Conservation News.] {{National parks of Russia}} {{Europe in topic|List of national parks of|countries_only=yes}} [[Category:National parks of Russia| ]] [[Category:Lists of national parks|Russia]] [[Category:Russia geography-related lists|National parks]] [[Category:Lists of tourist attractions in Russia|National parks]]

revision.comment: Successfully de-orphaned! Wikiproject Orphanage: [[Wikipedia:ORPHAN|You can help!]]
Adding 0 [[arXiv|arxiv eprint(s)]], 7 [[bibcode|bibcode(s)]] and 0 [[digital object identifier|doi(s)]]. Did it miss something? Report bugs, errors, and suggestions at [[User talk:Bibcode Bot]]
revision.text:
{{redirects here|Rafting event|using rafts as a sport or pleasure event|Rafting}}
'''Oceanic dispersal''' is a type of [[biological dispersal]] that occurs when terrestrial organisms transfer from one land mass to another by way of a sea crossing. Often this occurs via large rafts of floating vegetation such as are sometimes seen floating down major rivers in the tropics and washing out to sea, occasionally with animals trapped on them.<ref name=Mittermeier>{{cite book | last = Mittermeier | first = R.A. | authorlink = Russell Mittermeier | title = Lemurs of Madagascar | edition = 2nd | publisher = Conservation International | year = 2006 | pages = 24–26 | isbn=1-881173-88-7|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Dispersal via such a raft is sometimes referred to as a "rafting event".
Colonization of land masses by plants can also occur via long-distance oceanic dispersal of floating seeds.<ref name="Won2">{{cite journal | last1 = Won | first1 = H. | last2 = Renner | first2 = S. S. | year = 2006 | title = Dating dispersal and radiation in the gymnosperm ''Gnetum'' (Gnetales) – clock calibration when outgroup relationships are uncertain | url = | journal = Systematic Biology | volume = 55 | issue = 4| pages = 610–622 | doi = 10.1080/10635150600812619 | pmid=16969937}}</ref>
==History== Rafting has played an important role in the colonization of isolated land masses by mammals. Prominent examples include [[Madagascar]], which has been isolated for ~120 million years ([[Year#SI prefix multipliers|Ma]]), and [[South America]], which was isolated for much of the [[Cenozoic]]. Both land masses, for example, appear to have received their [[primate]]s by this mechanism. According to genetic evidence, the common ancestor of the [[lemur]]s of [[Madagascar]] appears to have crossed the [[Mozambique Channel]] by rafting between 50 and 60 Ma ago.<ref name=Roos>{{cite journal | first = Christian | last = Roos |author2=Schmitz, Jürgen |author3=Zischler, Hans | title = Primate jumping genes elucidate strepsirrhine phylogeny | journal = PNAS | date = July 2004 | volume = 101 | pages = 10650–10654 | url = http://www.pnas.org/content/101/29/10650.full.pdf | format = PDF | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0403852101 | pmid = 15249661 | issue = 29 | pmc = 489989 | bibcode=2004PNAS..10110650R}}</ref><ref name=Sellers>{{cite web | url = http://homepage.mac.com/wis/Personal/lectures/human-origins/PrimateEvolution.pdf | title = Primate Evolution | accessdate = 2008-10-23 | last = Sellers | first = Bill | date = 2000-10-20 | format = PDF | publisher = [[University of Edinburgh]] | pages = 13–17}}</ref><ref name = "Ali&Huber">{{Cite journal | last = Ali | first = J. R. |author2=Huber, M. | title = Mammalian biodiversity on Madagascar controlled by ocean currents | journal = [[Nature (journal)|Nature]] | volume = 463 | issue = 4 Feb. 2010 | pages = 653–656 | publisher = [[Nature Publishing Group]] | date = 2010-01-20 | url = http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/nature08706.html | doi = 10.1038/nature08706 | accessdate = 2010-01-20 | pmid = 20090678 | bibcode=2010Natur.463..653A}}</ref> Likewise, the [[New World monkey]]s are thought to have originated in [[Africa]] and rafted to [[South America]] by the [[Oligocene]], when the continents were much closer than they are today.<ref name=Sellers/> Madagascar also appears to have received its [[Tenrecidae|tenrecs]] (25–42 Ma ago), [[Nesomyidae|nesomyid]] rodents (20–24 Ma ago) and [[Eupleridae|euplerid]] carnivorans (19–26 Ma ago) by this route<ref name = "Ali&Huber"/> and South America its [[Caviomorpha|caviomorph]] rodents (over 30 Ma ago).<ref>{{cite journal | title=Recent advances in South American mammalian paleontology |author1=Flynn, J. J. |author2=Wyss, A. R. | journal=Trends in Ecology and Evolution | volume=13 | issue=11| pages=449–454| year=1998 | doi= 10.1016/S0169-5347(98)01457-8 | pmid=21238387 }}</ref><ref name = SciAm>{{cite journal| title=South America's Missing Mammals |author1=Flynn, John J. |author2=Wyss, André R. |author3=Charrier, Reynaldo|author-link3=Reynaldo Charrier | journal=[[Scientific American]]| volume=| issue= May| pages= 68–75| year= 2007 | url= http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=south-americas-missing-mammals }}</ref> [[simian|Simian primates]] (ancestral to monkeys) and [[Hystricognathi|hystricognath]] rodents (ancestral to caviomorphs) are believed to have previously rafted from Asia to Africa about 40 Ma ago.<ref name = "Chaimanee">{{Cite journal | last1 = Chaimanee | first1 = Y. | last2 = Chavasseau | first2 = O. | last3 = Beard | first3 = K. C. | last4 = Kyaw | first4 = A. A. | last5 = Soe | first5 = A. N. | last6 = Sein | first6 = C. | last7 = Lazzari | first7 = V. | last8 = Marivaux | first8 = L. | last9 = Marandat | first9 = B. | last10 = Swe | first10 = M. | last11 = Rugbumrung | first11 = M. | last12 = Lwin | first12 = T. | last13 = Valentin | first13 = X. | last14 = Zin-Maung-Maung-Thein | last15 = Jaeger | first15 = J. -J. | title = Late Middle Eocene primate from Myanmar and the initial anthropoid colonization of Africa | doi = 10.1073/pnas.1200644109 | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | volume = 109 | issue = 26 | pages = 10293 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22665790| pmc = 3387043| ref = harv | bibcode = 2012PNAS..10910293C }}</ref>
Among reptiles, [[Brachylophus|several iguanid species]] in the South Pacific have been hypothesized to be descended from iguanas that rafted {{convert|10000|km}} from Central or South America<ref name="Gibbons">{{Cite journal | last = Gibbons | first = J. R. H. | title = The Biogeography of ''Brachylophus'' (Iguanidae) including the Description of a New Species, ''B. vitiensis'', from Fiji | journal = Journal of Herpetology | volume = 15 | issue = 3 | pages = 255–273 | publisher = Society for the Study of Amphibians and Reptiles | location = | date = Jul 31, 1981 | issn = | doi = 10.2307/1563429| id = | jstor=1563429}}</ref> (an alternative theory involves dispersal of a putative now-extinct iguana lineage from Australia or Asia<ref name="Noonan">{{cite journal|author1=Noonan, B.P. |author2=Sites, J. W., Jr. |date= 2009-11-24|title=Tracing the origins of iguanid lizards and boine snakes of the Pacific|publisher=[[University of Chicago Press]]|pages=61–72|doi=10.1086/648607|volume=175 |pmid=19929634 |issue=1 |journal=[[The American Naturalist]]}}</ref>). Similarly, a number of [[clade]]s of American [[gecko]]s seem to have rafted over from Africa during both the Paleogene and Neogene.<ref name = "Gamble2010">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1111/j.1420-9101.2010.02184.x| title = Coming to America: Multiple origins of New World geckos| journal = Journal of Evolutionary Biology| volume = 24| issue = 2| pages = 231–244| date = 2010-12-03| last1 = Gamble | first1 = T.| last2 = Bauer | first2 = A. M.| last3 = Colli | first3 = G. R.| last4 = Greenbaum | first4 = E.| last5 = Jackman | first5 = T. R.| last6 = Vitt | first6 = L. J.| last7 = Simons | first7 = A. M.| url = http://www.tc.umn.edu/~gambl007/publications/Gamble_etal_2011_jeb.pdf | pmid=21126276 | pmc=3075428}}</ref> [[Skink]]s of the related genera ''[[Mabuya]]'' and ''[[Trachylepis]]'' also apparently both floated across the Atlantic from Africa to South America and [[Fernando de Noronha]], respectively, during the last 9 Ma.<ref name = "Carranza">{{cite journal | last = Carranza | first = S. |author2=Arnold, N. E. | title = Investigating the origin of transoceanic distributions: mtDNA shows ''Mabuya'' lizards (Reptilia, Scincidae) crossed the Atlantic twice | journal = Systematics and Biodiversity | volume = 1 | issue = 2 | pages = 275–282 | publisher = Cambridge University Press | date = 2003-08-05 | url = http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=168963 | doi= 10.1017/S1477200003001099 | accessdate = 2008-04-04}}</ref> Skinks from the same group have also rafted from Africa to [[Cape Verde]], Madagascar, the [[Seychelles]], the [[Comoros]] and [[Socotra]].<ref name = "Carranza"/> (Among lizards, skinks and geckos seem especially capable of surviving long transoceanic journeys.<ref name = "Carranza"/>) Surprisingly, even burrowing [[amphisbaenia]]ns<ref name = "Vidal2007">{{Cite journal | last1 = Vidal | first1 = N. | last2 = Azvolinsky | first2 = A. | last3 = Cruaud | first3 = C. | last4 = Hedges | first4 = S. B. | title = Origin of tropical American burrowing reptiles by transatlantic rafting | doi = 10.1098/rsbl.2007.0531 | journal = Biology Letters | volume = 4 | issue = 1 | pages = 115–118 | date = 2007-12-11 | pmid = 18077239| pmc =2412945 }}</ref> and [[blind snake]]s<ref name = "Vidal2010">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1098/rsbl.2010.0220| title = Blindsnake evolutionary tree reveals long history on Gondwana| journal = Biology Letters| volume = 6| issue = 4| pages = 558–561| date = 2010-03-31| last1 = Vidal | first1 = N.| last2 = Marin | first2 = J.| last3 = Morini | first3 = M.| last4 = Donnellan | first4 = S.| last5 = Branch | first5 = W. R.| last6 = Thomas | first6 = R.| last7 = Vences | first7 = M.| last8 = Wynn | first8 = A.| last9 = Cruaud | first9 = C.| last10 = Hedges | first10 = S. B. | pmid=20356885 | pmc=2936224}}</ref> appear to have rafted from Africa to South America.
An example of a bird that is thought to have reached its present location by rafting is the weak-flying South American [[hoatzin]], whose ancestors apparently floated over from Africa.<ref name = "Mayr2011">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1007/s00114-011-0849-1| title = Out of Africa: Fossils shed light on the origin of the hoatzin, an iconic Neotropic bird| journal = Naturwissenschaften| volume = 98| issue = 11| pages = 961–966| date = 2011-10-01| last1 = Mayr | first1 = G. | last2 = Alvarenga | first2 = H. | last3 = Mourer-Chauviré | first3 = C. C. | pmid=21964974| bibcode = 2011NW.....98..961M}}</ref>
Colonization of groups of islands can occur by an [[Iteration|iterative]] rafting process sometimes called [[island hopping]]. Such a process appears to have played a role, for example, in the colonization of the [[Caribbean]] by [[Mammals of the Caribbean|mammals of South American origin]] (including caviomorphs and monkeys).<ref name = "Hedges2006">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.3417/0026-6493(2006)93[231:POTAAO]2.0.CO;2| title = Paleogeography of the Antilles and Origin of West Indian Terrestrial Vertebrates1| journal = [[Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden]]| volume = 93| issue = 2| pages = 231–244| year = 2006| last1 = Hedges | first1 = S. Blair}}</ref>
A remarkable example of iterative rafting has been proposed for spiders of the genus ''[[List of Anyphaenidae species#Amaurobioides|Amaurobioides]]''.<ref name = "Kukso2016">{{cite web | url = https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/seafaring-spiders-made-it-around-the-world-in-8-million-years/ | title = Seafaring Spiders Made It around the World—in 8 Million Years | last = Kukso | first = F. | date = 2016-11-08 | website = [[Scientific American]] | access-date = 2016-11-10}}</ref><ref name="Kuntner2016">{{cite journal|last1= Kuntner|first1=M.|last2= Ceccarelli|first2=F. S.|last3= Opell|first3=B. D.|last4= Haddad|first4=C. R.|last5= Raven|first5=Robert J.|last6= Soto|first6=E. M.|last7= Ramírez|first7=M. J.|title=Around the World in Eight Million Years: Historical Biogeography and Evolution of the Spray Zone Spider ''Amaurobioides'' (Araneae: Anyphaenidae)|journal=PLOS One|volume= 11|issue= 10|date= 2016-10-12|pages= e0163740|doi= 10.1371/journal.pone.0163740|pmid=27732621|pmc=5061358|bibcode=2016PLoSO..1163740C}}</ref> Members of this genus inhabit coastal sites and build silken cells which they seal at high tide; however, they do not [[Ballooning (spider)|balloon]]. DNA sequence analysis suggests that ancestors of the genus dispersed from southern South America to South Africa about 10 million years (Ma) ago, where the most [[Basal (phylogenetics)|basal]] clade is found; subsequent rafting events then took the genus eastward with the [[Antarctic Circumpolar Current]] to Australia, then to New Zealand and finally to Chile by about 2 Ma ago.<ref name="Kuntner2016" /> Another example among spiders is the species ''[[Moggridgea rainbowi]]'', the only Australian member of a genus otherwise endemic to Africa, with a divergence date of 2 to 16 Ma ago.<ref name="Kuntner2017">{{cite journal|last1=Kuntner|first1=M.|last2=Harrison|first2=S. E.|last3=Harvey|first3=M. S.|last4=Cooper|first4=S. J. B.|last5=Austin|first5=A. D.|last6=Rix|first6=M. G.|title=Across the Indian Ocean: A remarkable example of trans-oceanic dispersal in an austral mygalomorph spider|journal=PLOS One|volume=12|issue=8|year=2017|page=e0180139|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0180139|bibcode=2017PLoSO..1280139H}}</ref>
However, oceanic dispersal of terrestrial species may not always take the form of rafting; in some cases, swimming or simply floating may suffice. Tortoises of the genus ''[[Chelonoidis]]'' arrived in South America from Africa in the Oligocene;<ref name = "Le et al.">{{cite journal | last = Le | first = M. |author2=Raxworthy, C. J. |author3=McCord, W. P. |author4=Mertz, L. | title = A molecular phylogeny of tortoises (Testudines: Testudinidae) based on mitochondrial and nuclear genes | journal = Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution | volume = 40 | issue = 2 | pages = 517–531 | date = 2006-05-05 | url = https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1055790306000856 | doi = 10.1016/j.ympev.2006.03.003 | pmid = 16678445 }}</ref> they were probably aided by their ability to float with their heads up, and to survive up to six months without food or fresh water.<ref name = "Le et al."/> South American tortoises then went on to colonize the [[West Indies]] and [[Galápagos tortoise|Galápagos Islands]]. The dispersal of [[anthracothere]]s from Asia to Africa about 40 Ma ago,<ref name = "Chaimanee"/> and the much more recent dispersal of [[hippopotamus|hippo]]s (relatives and probably descendants of anthracotheres) from Africa to Madagascar may have occurred by floating or swimming.<ref name = "Ali&Huber"/>
==Observation== The first documented example of colonization of a land mass by rafting occurred in the aftermath of hurricanes [[Hurricane Luis|Luis]] and [[Hurricane Marilyn|Marilyn]] in the [[Caribbean]] in 1995. A raft of uprooted trees carrying fifteen or more [[green iguana]]s was observed by fishermen landing on the east side of [[Anguilla]] – an island where they had never before been recorded.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Lawrence|first=E.|date=1998-10-15|title=Iguanas ride the waves|journal=Nature|doi=10.1038/news981015-3}}</ref> The iguanas had apparently been caught on the trees and rafted two hundred miles across the ocean from [[Guadeloupe]], where they are indigenous.<ref name="Censky1998">{{cite journal|last1= Censky|first1=E. J.|last2= Hodge|first2=K.|last3= Dudley|first3= J.|journal= Nature|title= Over-water dispersal of lizards due to hurricanes|volume= 395|issue= 6702|date= 1998-10-08|page= 556|doi=10.1038/26886|bibcode= 1998Natur.395..556C}}</ref><ref name="Yoon1998">{{cite news | last = Yoon | first = C. K. | title = ''Hapless iguanas float away and voyage grips biologists'' | publisher = The New York Times | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/08/us/hapless-iguanas-float-away-and-voyage-grips-biologists.html | date = 1998-10-08}}</ref> Examination of the weather patterns and ocean currents indicated that they had probably spent three weeks at sea before landfall.<ref name="Yoon1998"/> This colony began breeding on the new island within two years of its arrival.<ref name="Yoon1998"/>
The advent of human civilization has created opportunities for organisms to raft on floating artifacts, which may be more durable than natural floating objects. This phenomenon was noted following the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|2011 Tōhoku tsunami]] in Japan, with about 300 species found to have been carried on debris by the [[North Pacific Current]] to the west coast of North America (although no colonizations have been detected thus far).<ref name="Chown2017">{{cite journal|last1= Chown|first1=S. L.|title= Tsunami debris spells trouble|journal= Science|volume= 357|issue= 6358|year= 2017|pages= 1356–1356|doi= 10.1126/science.aao5677|bibcode= 2017Sci...357.1356C}}</ref><ref name="Carlton2017">{{cite journal|last1= Carlton|first1=J. T.|last2= Chapman|first2=J. W.|last3= Geller|first3=J. B.|last4= Miller|first4=J. A.|last5= Carlton|first5=D. A.|last6= McCuller|first6=M. I.|last7= Treneman|first7=N. C.|last8= Steves|first8=B. P.|last9= Ruiz|first9=G. M.|title= Tsunami-driven rafting: Transoceanic species dispersal and implications for marine biogeography|journal= Science|volume= 357|issue= 6358|year= 2017|pages= 1402–1406|doi= 10.1126/science.aao1498|pmid=28963256|bibcode=2017Sci...357.1402C}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Allopatric speciation]] * [[Biological dispersal]] * [[Panspermia]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== Further reading == *{{cite web | last = de Queiroz | first = A. | title = Evolution’s Stowaways | work = [[The Scientist (magazine)|The Scientist]] | publisher = LabX Media Group | date = 2014-01-01 | url = http://www.the-scientist.com//?articles.view/articleNo/38709/title/Evolution-s-Stowaways/ | accessdate = 2014-01-16}} *{{cite book|author=de Queiroz, A.|title=The Monkey's Voyage: How Improbable Journeys Shaped the History of Life|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2mJvLwEACAAJ|date=7 January 2014|publisher=Basic Books|isbn=978-0-465-02051-5|oclc=858975420}}
{{speciation}} {{evolution}}
[[Category:Biogeography]] [[Category:Biological evolution]] [[Category:Evolutionary biology]] [[Category:Speciation|*]]

revision.comment: Removing links to deleted file [[:File:Molding-ogee.png]]
revision.text:
{{About||the cartoon character named "Ogee"|Magilla Gorilla}} {{Distinguish|Ogive}} [[File:Pirna Peter-Ulrich-Haus (01).JPG|thumb|An ogee-arched doorway in [[Pirna]], Germany]] [[File:Ogee-shaped arch.svg|thumb|Component pieces of ogee arch]] <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Molding-ogee.png|thumb|Ogee [[molding (decorative)|moulding]] and its shadow pattern.]] --> An '''ogee''' ({{IPAc-en|oʊ|ˈ|dʒ|iː}} {{IPAc-en|ˈ|oʊ|dʒ|iː}}) is a [[curve]] (often used in [[molding (decorative)|moulding]]), shaped somewhat like an S, consisting of two [[arc (geometry)|arc]]s that curve in opposite senses, so that the ends are [[Parallel (geometry)|parallel]]. It is a kind of [[sigmoid curve]].
The term has uses in [[architecture]], [[mathematics]], and [[fluid mechanics]], as well as marine [[construction]], [[clock design]] and [[plastic surgery]].
Ogee is also written '''O.G.'''. This long-standing variant may have originated from a mis-hearing of the spoken word ''ogee'' as an abbreviation. Nevertheless, the quasi-abbreviation is often seen in print within the millwork trade.
__TOC__
==Use in architecture== ===Ogee arch=== [[File:Kilfane Church, 13th Century Door Thomastown, Co. Kilkenny.jpg|thumb|An unorthodox ogee arch in [[Kilfane Church]], Ireland (13th century)]] In architecture, the principal use of the term is to describe an [[arch]] composed of two ogees, mirrored left-to-right and meeting at an apex.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Davies|first1=Nikolas|last2=Jokiniemi|first2=Erkki|title=Architect's Illustrated Pocket Dictionary|year=2011|publisher=Architectural Press|location=Oxford, England|isbn=978-0-08-096537-6|page=318}}</ref> Ogee arches were a feature of [[English Gothic architecture]] in the later thirteenth century.<ref name=HF>[[Hugh Honour|Honour, H.]] and J. Fleming, (2009) ''A World History of Art''. 7th edn. London: Laurence King Publishing, p. 391. {{isbn|9781856695848}}</ref>
===Moulding=== A building's surface detailing (indoors or out) may have a [[molding (decorative)|moulding]] with an ogee-shaped profile, consisting (going from low to high) of a [[wikt:concave|concave]] arc flowing into a [[wikt:convex|convex]] arc, with vertical ends; if the lower curve is convex and higher one concave, this is known as a [[Roman ogee]], although frequently the terms are used as if they are interchangeable and for a variety of other shapes. Alternative names for such a true Roman ogee moulding include ''cyma reversa'' and ''talon''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Parker|first=John Henry|authorlink=John Henry Parker|title=A glossary of terms used in Grecian, Roman, Italian, and Gothic Architecture|volume=1|year=1850|publisher=David Bogue|location=London|page=159|oclc=719426|quote=Cyma recta…which is hollow in the upper part, and round in the lower; and Cyma reversa, (Talon…) which is hollow in the lower part and round in the upper.}}</ref>
The [[cyma reversa]] form occurs in antiquity. For example, in ancient [[Persia]], the [[Tomb of Cyrus]] featured the cyma reversa.<ref>C.Michael Hogan (2008) [http://www.megalithic.co.uk/article.php?sid=18264 ''Tomb of Cyrus''], The Megalithic Portal, ed. A.{{Page needed|date=December 2009}}</ref> The cyma reversa is also evident in [[ancient Greek architecture]], and takes its name from the [[cymatium]].<ref>W.B.Dinsmoor, 1973{{Page needed|date=December 2009}}</ref> The ogee shape is one of the characteristics of the [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] style of [[architecture]], especially decorative elements in the 14th and 15th century late Gothic styles called [[Flamboyant]] in [[France]] and [[Decorated Period|Decorated]] in [[England]]. Ogee windows and arches were introduced to European cities from the [[Middle East]]. The ogee curve is an analogue of a "[[Molding (decorative)#Types|cyma]] curve", the difference being that a cyma has horizontal rather than vertical ends.
The ogee and Roman ogee profiles are used in decorative moulding, often framed between mouldings with a square section. As such it is part of the standard classical decorative vocabulary, adopted from architrave and cornice mouldings of the [[Ionic order]] and [[Corinthian order]]. An ogee is also often used in the "[[crown moulding]]" frequently found at the top of a piece of [[case furniture]], or for capping a [[baseboard]] or [[plinth]], or where a wall meets the ceiling. An ogee moulding may be run in plaster or wood, or cut in stone or brickwork.
==Other uses== [[File:Eli Terry Ogee clock.jpg|thumb|150px|Ogee clock, framed with ogee moulding.]] Ogee is also a mathematical term, meaning an [[inflection point]].
In [[fluid mechanics]], the term is used for an ogee-shaped [[aerodynamics|aerodynamic]] profile. For example, a wing may have ogee profile, particularly on supersonic aircraft such as the [[Concorde]]. Also, the downstream face of a dam [[spillway#Chute spillway|spillway]] is usually formed in an ogee curve to minimize water pressure.
An "ogee washer" is a heavy washer with a large bearing surface used in marine timber construction to prevent bolt heads or nuts from sinking into the face of timbers. The term ogee is used due to the ogee shape in radial symmetry around the centre. Due to the size and shape, they are generally manufactured as a cast iron product in accordance with ASTM A47 or A48.
An "ogee clock" is a common kind of weight-driven 19th-century [[pendulum clock]] in a simplified Gothic taste, made in the United States for a mantelpiece or to sit upon a wall bracket. It is rectangular, with ogee-profile moulding that frames a central glass door that protects the clock face and the pendulum. The weights fall inside the ogee moulding supported by pulleys and hidden from view. The door usually carries a painted scene in the area beneath the face. Ogee clocks are one of the most commonly encountered varieties of American antique clocks. The design is usually attributed to [[Chauncey Jerome]].<ref>{{Cite book |title=New Haven Clocks & Watches |last=Ly |first=Tran Duy |date=1997 |work=New Haven Clocks & Watches |publisher=Arlington Press |isbn=0930163753}}</ref>
In aesthetic facial surgery, the term is used to describe the malar or cheekbone prominence transitioning into the mid-cheek hollow. The aim of a mid-face rejuvenation is to restore the ogee curve and enhance the cheekbones. This enhancement is also commonly a part of a routine [[facelift]].
In distillation, an ogee is the bubble-shaped chamber of a pot still that connects the swan neck to the pot. It allows distillate to expand, condense, and fall back into the pot.
==See also== *[[Ogive]]
==References and sources== ;References {{reflist}} ;Sources {{Commons category|Ogees}} * William Bell Dinsmoor and William James Anderson (1973) ''The architecture of ancient Greece: an account of its historic development'', Biblo & Tannen Publishers, 424 pages {{isbn|0-8196-0283-3}}. * C.Michael Hogan (2008) [http://www.megalithic.co.uk/article.php?sid=18264 ''Tomb of Cyrus''], The Megalithic Portal, ed. A. * The Art of Distilling Whiskey, By Bill Owens And Alan Dikty, 2009. Page 26
{{Woodworking}}

Natural gas | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = [[Eneco Energie]] | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Oxxio''' is an [[electricity]] and [[natural gas]] [[utility]] located in [[Rotterdam]], [[Netherlands]]. It is a subsidiary of [[Eneco Energie]]. Oxxio serves about 800,000 customers in the Netherlands. It is the fourth largest supplier and the largest of the companies that entered the market since the energy market liberalisation in 2000.{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In 2005, [[Centrica]] acquired Oxxio. In March 2011, Oxxio was acquired by [[Eneco Energie]] for €72 million. {{cite press release |url= http://corporateuk.eneco.nl/News_and_Media/pressreleases/Pages/Eneco-acquires-Oxxio.aspx |title= Eneco acquires Oxxio |publisher= [[Eneco Energie]] |date= 2011-03-24 |accessdate= 2012-02-13}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Portal|Energy|Companies}} * {{nl}} [http://www.oxxio.nl Oxxio website] [[Category:Power companies of the Netherlands]] [[Category:Centrica]] {{energy-company-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Plasma Modeling''' refers to solving [[equations of motion]] that describe the state of a [[plasma (physics)|plasma]]. It is generally coupled with [[Maxwell's Equations]] for [[electromagnetic field]]s or [[Poisson's Equation]] for electrostatic fields. There are several main types of plasma models: single particle, kinetic, fluid, hybrid kinetic/fluid, gyrokinetic and as system of many particles.
[[Image:A Comparison Chart For Modeling Plasma2.png|800px|Image: 800 pixels|Chart for modeling plasma|right|Image on right]]
==Single Particle Description== The single particle model describes the plasma as individual electrons and ions moving in imposed (rather than self-consistent) electric and magnetic fields. The motion of each particle is thus described by the [[Lorentz Force Law]]. In many cases of practical interest, this motion can be treated as the superposition of a relatively fast circular motion around a point called the [[guiding center]] and a relatively slow drift of this point.
==Kinetic Description== The kinetic model is the most fundamental way to describe a plasma, resultantly producing a [[Distribution function (physics)|distribution function]] :<math>f(\vec{x},\vec{v},t)</math> where the independent variables <math>\vec{x}</math> and <math>\vec{v}</math> are [[position (vector)|position]] and [[velocity]], respectively. A kinetic description is achieved by solving the [[Boltzmann equation]] or, when the correct description of long-range [[Coulomb's law|Coulomb interaction]] is necessary, by the [[Vlasov equation]] which contains self-consistent collective electromagnetic field, or by the [[Fokker-Planck equation]], in which approximations have been used to derive manageable collision terms. The charges and currents produced by the distribution functions self-consistently determine the electromagnetic fields via [[Maxwell's equations]].
==Fluid Description== To reduce the complexities in the kinetic description, the fluid model describes the plasma based on macroscopic quantities (velocity moments of the distribution such as density, mean velocity, and mean energy). The equations for macroscopic quantities, called fluid equations, are obtained by taking velocity moments of the [[Boltzmann equation]] or the [[Vlasov equation]]. The fluid equations are not closed without the determination of transport coefficients such as mobility, [[diffusion coefficient]], averaged collision frequencies, and so on. To determine the transport coefficients, the velocity distribution function must be assumed/chosen. But this assumption can lead to a failure of capturing some physics.
==Hybrid Kinetic/Fluid Description== Although the kinetic model describes the physics accurately, it is more complex (and in the case of numerical simulations, more computationally intensive) than the fluid model. The hybrid model is a combination of fluid and kinetic models, treating some components of the system as a fluid, and others kinetically.
==Gyrokinetic Description== In the [[Gyrokinetics|gyrokinetic model]], which is appropriate to systems with a strong background magnetic field, the kinetic equations are averaged over the fast circular motion of the [[gyroradius]]. This model has been used extensively for simulation of [[tokamak]] plasma instabilities (for example, the [[GYRO]] and [[Gyrokinetic ElectroMagnetic]] codes), and more recently in astrophysical applications.
==Quantum Mechanical Methods== Quantum methods are not yet very common in plasma modeling. They can be used to solve unique modeling problems; like situations where other methods do not apply.<ref>“A different approach to the MHD equilibrium” Hedditch, John August 2nd, 2018, 4 Pages, submitted to Physics of Plasmas, ArXiv <https://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00622>.</ref> They involve the application of [[Quantum Field Theory]] to plasma. In these cases, the [[electric]] and [[magnetic]] fields made by particles are modeled like a [[Field (mathematics)|field]]; A web of forces. Particles that move, or are removed from the population push and pull on this web of forces, this field. The mathematical treatment for this involves [[Lagrangian mechanics|Lagrangian]] mathematics.
==Commercial Plasma Physics Modeling Codes== *[http://esgeetech.com/products/vizglow/ VizGlow] *[http://esgeetech.com/products/vizspark-thermal-plasma-modeling/ VizSpark] *[https://www.esi-group.com/software-services/virtual-environment/cfd-multiphysics/ace-suite/cfd-ace CFD-ACE+] *[http://www.comsol.com/ COMSOL] *[http://www.lspsuite.com/ LSP] *[http://www.northropgrumman.com/Capabilities/PICCodeSoftware/MAGIC/Pages/About-Magic.aspx Magic] *[http://www.particleincell.com/starfish/ Starfish] *[http://www.txcorp.com/ USim] *[http://www.txcorp.com VSim]
==See also== *[[List of plasma (physics) articles]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
*{{cite book | author=Francis F. Chen | title=Introduction to Plasma Physics and Controlled Fusion | edition=2nd | publisher=Springer | date=2006 | isbn=978-0-306-41332-2 }} *{{cite book | author=Nicholas Krall | author2=Alvin Trivelpiece | last-author-amp=yes | title=Principles of Plasma Physics | publisher=San Francisco Press| date=1986 | isbn=978-0-911302-58-5 }} *{{cite journal|last=Ledvina|first=S. A.|author2=Y.-J. Ma|author3=E. Kallio|title=Modeling and Simulating Flowing Plasmas and Related Phenomena|journal=Space Science Reviews|date=2008|volume=139|issue=1–4|pages=143|doi=10.1007/s11214-008-9384-6|bibcode = 2008SSRv..139..143L }}
